properties.Title: Civil Emergency, Update From Sk Provincial Emergency Communications Centre
properties.Summary:
Description: This emergency advisory alert is being issued for the province of Saskatchewan. All travelers returning from outside of Canada are subject to a mandatory 14 day self isolation order. Violation of the order may result in a fine of 2000 dollars.
Expires: 2021-03-31T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2021-03-17T16:30:35-06:00, A32385F2-98FB-8B10-4148-DC3489465349
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow is possible Friday. Locations: southwestern, western, and parts of central Newfoundland. Time span: early Friday to late Friday afternoon. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin this afternoon or evening and is expected to change to snow overnight tonight into Friday morning. At this time only 5 to 10 cm of snow is forecast for these areas, but due to some uncertainty higher amounts could shift into these regions. Should the system shift westward, as much as 10 to 15 cm could fall in some areas. Please continue to monitor future forecasts in case snowfall warnings are required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T23:45:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T07:46:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3581766570.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Friday. Accumulation: 15 cm or more. Location: Guysborough, Richmond and Sydney Metro and Cape Breton Counties. Remarks: Rain will change to snow, at times heavy, early Friday morning and will taper off by Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be along the Atlantic coast, with lesser amounts expected inland. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-18T23:46:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T07:47:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0082477841.2021
Area: Guysborough County, Richmond County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow expected Friday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Locally higher amounts are possible in some locations. Locations: parts of southwestern, northeastern, and central Newfoundland. Time span: Early Friday morning to Friday evening. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin this evening before changing to snow by Friday morning. The snow may be heavy at times along the southwest coast this afternoon and evening before transitioning briefly to rain later in the evening. The combination of rain followed by snow and falling temperatures will likely lead to very slippery road conditions on Friday. Conditions will improve Friday evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T23:45:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T07:46:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1904665675.2021
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR GOLDEN (March 17, 2021 08:00 - Cranbrook) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Interior Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Golden because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is a concern for pregnant women, infants, and older adults, as well as, individuals with conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, diabetes or respiratory infections such as COVID-19. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-18T20:48:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-18T04:49:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1524702700.2021
Area: East Columbia
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain expected Thursday night then significant snow on Friday. Total snowfall: 10 to 25 cm. Total rainfall: 5 to 10 mm. Locations: southwestern, northeastern, and central Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will begin either Thursday afternoon or evening before changing to snow on Friday. The snow may be heavy at times along the southwest coast Thursday afternoon and evening before the transition to rain later in the evening. The combination of rain followed by snow and falling temperatures will likely lead to very slippery road conditions. Snowfall warnings may be required for Friday. Conditions will improve Friday afternoon or Friday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T19:16:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T03:17:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3202705987.2021
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected on Friday. Total snowfall: generally 10 cm, with 15 cm or more possible over eastern Nova Scotia. Location: most of Nova Scotia. Remarks: Rain will change to snow early Friday morning then taper off Friday afternoon. The highest accumulations will be over eastern Nova Scotia. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE March 16, 2021 14:00 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-18T20:49:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-03-18T04:50:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2343704237.2021
Area: Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and wind expected followed by potentially significant snowfall Thursday night and Friday. Total rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm. Potential snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: southwesterly near 60 km/h. Locations: the Connaigre, Burin, and Bonavista peninsulas, as well as the Terra Nova and Clarenville areas. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will begin Thursday night and become heavy at times on Friday. Strong southerly winds will accompany the rain, combining with temperatures well above freezing to cause considerable snow melt. If possible, storm drains should be cleared before Thursday night, as a combination of rain, snow melt, and runoff will likely lead to minor flooding in areas where pooling water cannot drain properly. Rainfall warnings will likely be required for Friday. Rain will change to potentially significant snow Friday afternoon or evening with a period of freezing rain or ice pellets possible during the transition. Note that as temperatures fall below freezing Friday night, conditions will likely become quite icy. Conditions will improve overnight Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T19:16:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T03:17:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3973535615.2021
Area: Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: along the Labrador coast from Rigolet to Hopedale. Time span: overnight tonight and Friday morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northwesterly winds tonight to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions will improve around noon on Friday. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-19T00:11:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T08:12:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4178880425.2021
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall and wind expected Thursday night and Friday. Total rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm. Maximum wind gusts: southerly between 80 and 100 km/h. Locations: The Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Thursday evening to Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will begin Thursday evening and become heavy at times on Friday. Strong southerly winds will accompany the rain, combining with temperatures well above freezing to cause considerable snow melt. If possible, storm drains should be cleared before Thursday night, as a combination of rain, snow melt, and runoff will likely lead to minor flooding in areas where pooling water cannot drain properly. Rainfall warnings will likely be required for Friday. Rain will change to snow Friday evening with a period of freezing rain or ice pellets possible during the transition. Note that as temperatures fall below freezing Friday night, conditions will likely become quite icy. Conditions will improve overnight Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T19:13:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T03:14:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2702663816.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Significant rainfall and wind expected tonight and Friday. Total rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm over the Burin and Avalon Peninsulas, 15 to 30 mm elsewhere. Maximum wind gusts: southerly between 80 and 100 km/h. Locations: The Avalon, Burin, Connaigre, and Bonavista peninsulas, including Clarenville and Terra Nova. Time span: this evening to Friday evening. Remarks: Rain will begin this evening and become heavy at times on Friday. Strong southerly winds will accompany the rain, combining with temperatures well above freezing to cause considerable snow melt. If possible, storm drains should be cleared before tonight, as a combination of rain, snow melt, and runoff will likely lead to minor flooding in areas where pooling water cannot drain properly. Rain will change to snow Friday afternoon or evening with a period of freezing rain or ice pellets possible during the transition. Note that as temperatures fall below freezing, conditions will likely become quite icy. Conditions will improve overnight Friday night. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-18T23:45:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-18T07:46:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4170905510.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada
